body: @Petahhh
@Petahhh for your review

Is there any reason why did not directly just tie the version to the `spring-framework-bom`?
`compile group: 'org.springframework', name: 'spring-framework-bom', version: '5.1.6.RELEASE', ext: 'pom'`

> Is there any reason why did not directly just tie the version to the `spring-framework-bom`?

nope, just lazy bumping numbers

In case we are using a replicated region, running get command we using get method from _LocalRegion.java_ after which stats are incremented correctly. 
In case using a partitioned region we using overridden get method from _PartitonedRegion.java_ which also at the end use increment method to update stats. But the problem is that in this overridden get method in **findObject**, get from _LocalRegion.java_ is also executed on bucker region, and in that case we have double increment for the same operation. 
So in this case there is unnecessarily to execute increment in _PartitonedRegion.java_ as it is already increment executing method **findObject**.
This does not require testing as this just updates the dependencies.
@Petahhh
@Petahhh for your review

A couple of comments about this PR which arose from feedback that we shouldn't be using a static accessor to a singleton `Cache` instance (`CacheFactory.getAnyInstance()` for example). Here are the highlights:
- Previously we had `ClusterManagementServiceFactory`s which had implementations in both `geode-management` and `geode-core`. These served as the (auto-magic) differentiators for the context that the user would call `ClusterManagementServiceProvider.getService()` in. Essentially these are replaced with `ClusterManagementServiceConfig` objects that a user has to explicitly configure and pass to `new ClientClusterManagementService(config)` to get an instance of `ClusterManagementService`. The auto-magicness is gone. The service loading shenanigans is also gone.
- The `ClusterManagementServiceConfig` objects are context dependent so a user does have to be aware of which impl they should be using.
- I applied a builder pattern to the creation of `ClusterManagementServiceConfig` objects. I think this is more flexible than constructors with a bunch of args (for which it isn't always clear which are required). In general, it's no problem adding an additional param to an existing builder pattern down the road. Also, builders are more flexible than setters as they are able to apply mutual exclusivity as part of API and not just at runtime.
- I think having a single entry point, into our API (now `new ClientClusterManagementService(config)`) is preferable to having separate classes. Could also do something like `JavaClientClusterManagementServiceProvider.getService(host, port)` and `GeodeClusterManagementServiceProvider.getService(cache)` but I think having the config object be the differentiator makes the API more discoverable.
- Lastly, retrieving the CMS on the locator is an outlier and is just `InternalLocator.getLocator().getClusterManagementService()`.
- I didn't bother updating comments since this might all still change.

I don't mind the suggested approach, although I do feel that a single entry-point into our API is better - it then allows for easier discovering of what different config classes are available - either through reading the docs or through using the API in an IDE.

@Petahhh
@bschuchardt The PutOpImpl constructor? The analyzer found that 99% of the code was identical. I collapsed it down to the diff.

Yeah the double locking is sort of odd at first glance.  Leaving an explanation here for posterity (also added comments which I hope clear things up for future generations):
There are two locks - one is for synchronizing between the put processing thread and the drain thread, and the other is to synchronize multiple drain threads.  The first one prevents new events from being added when the registration queue is drained.  The second one prevents multiple registration threads for the same client ID from draining the same queue.  So one synchronizes add/drain threads, and the other synchronizes multiple drain threads.  We can't use a single lock because of the optimization where we drain as many events as we can without taking out the addDrain write lock.  If we didn't do that, we could block the put processing threads for a significant amount of time if the registration queue was large.  This optimization was borrowed from the original registration queue implementation in the message dispatcher.
Closing this pr. Once https://github.com/apache/geode/pull/3512 is merged will redo this optimization, if needed, and open a new pull request.
Robert put a gun to my head. HONEST

@moleske The benchmarks are more for being able to test changes you may make in this area or comparing new algorithms you come up with. There is little value trying to run them in the CI. The runtime of some of these can be in the hours too.

> Won't the runtime optimize the compareTo call?

I don't know. I know that compareTo has to ask the InetAddress for a byte array representation of the address so that it can figure out if one address is greater or lessor than the other. It was these byte array allocations that showed up in the profiler. I think this would be garbage that the collector has to deal with. The new equals logic also has fewer conditions that it needs to test for but that was not the reason for this pull request and I doubt it would be much of a difference. If I could have found a way to change compareTo to not do the byte array allocations (by calling InetAddress.getAddress) I would have made that change add kept equals implemented by calling compareTo.
@Petahhh

You might consider adding/supporting both of these flavors:
* setSocketConnectTimeout(long, java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit)
* setSocketConnectTimeout(java.time.Duration)
GREEN!
Just for comparison: https://github.com/apache/geode/pull/3532/files

@kirklund I have thought about it and could commit either way. I shy away from it because:

* it requires heap allocation of an object
* cant be returned via get method because of the version with same signature returning int is still there, though deprecated.
* doesnt directly handle math rollover/under issues like `TimeUnit` does when converting units.

I love that its a single value but wish it fell somewhere between `Duration` and `TimeUnit` and was a value type and not an object. C++11 has a great version of this in `std::chrono::duration`.

I will whip up an implementation with `Duration` do we can see it side by side.
I also would vote for TImeUnit over Duration.

> Looking at how this method is used - I don't think the return type should even be a list. It's only used two throw an exception that uses the first two elements of the list. Also, it only returns a list if the values are different, which doesn't make sense with the name adviseSameGatewaySenderIds.
> 
> Maybe we should just refactor this to a method that does a check and throws an exception right in the advisor? Like checkSameGatewaySenderIds?

I think you right. I remember now noticing the same thing when I was profiling and working on this optimization. At that time I just wanted to get rid of the extra allocations but I do think changing this to have "check" methods would make the code much clearer. I will update this pull request.

I think the failed unit tests are caused by the product classes now calling getCachedString and I hope to find these tests mocking getString. If that is true then these tests can be changed to mock getCacheString.
@Petahhh
cc @geetrawat
A better fix is in: https://github.com/apache/geode/pull/3544. See: GEODE-6730

I still feel like having to create a config object first in order to create a client service is an extra burden for the user. Since this config object is the first thing user has to create, it still feels like a "different" entry point for me. I would rather use a different builder for simplicity.

Yep, this adds clarity and can prevent conversion errors.  It also ensures that we don't use the wrong precision (e.g. seconds where ms is needed).

The thing I would like to ensure is that when we add a timeout parameter+units to a method that the timeout is applied to the actual operation and not a derived value like SO_TIMEOUT.  So let's be really clear about what the timeout means to the end user.

> I like the performance improvement, and it looks like you are trying to get this check working without changing behavior, which is a good start.
> 
> I do wonder if we need to rethink how (or if) we should be validating this during a write operation. It seems like throwing this exception in the middle of the write operation (after cache update but before notifying any gateways) will result in data inconsistencies or at least inconsistent deliveries of events to gateways during the time window that someone is adding a new gateway. Is that even worse than not checking at all?

My first thought was the validation should be done at the time a new member joins or when a gateway or async event queue is added or removed. But the problem with the latter is that it is not a distributed operation so the user must add or remove it to multiple members manually. We could have the current check done by the write ops wait for a while when a difference is detected in hopes that the user is working on making it consistent. I asked @boglesby to take a look at this. Perhaps we need another ticket that does NOT focus on performance but on how and when sender id consistency should be checked.

I think we talked about removing that check back when we were doing the lucene work. Destroying a lucene index removes an AEQ id from the region, so a put was failing in the checkSameSenderIdsAvailableOnAllNodes call in notifyGatewaySender. We ended up adding the visibleAsyncEventQueueIds set and only checking that. Lucene AEQ ids don't get added to that set.

This issue is definitely in there for normal AEQ ids, though. One saving grace is that generally customers don't add AEQs to a region on the fly. They are there from the beginning.

Having that check on every put operation seems like overkill. I think it only has to be checked when a new member joins and when a new GatewaySender or AEQ is added or removed not using gfsh.

When a new member joins with different AEQ ids, this exception is thrown:
```
[error 2019/05/03 16:30:47.673 PDT <main> tid=0x1] java.lang.IllegalStateException: Cannot create Region /data with [ db2, db] async event ids because another cache has the same region defined with [db] async event ids

Exception in thread "main" java.lang.IllegalStateException: Cannot create Region /data with [ db2, db] async event ids because another cache has the same region defined with [db] async event ids
	at org.apache.geode.internal.cache.CreateRegionProcessor$CreateRegionMessage.handleCacheDistributionAdvisee(CreateRegionProcessor.java:466)
	at org.apache.geode.internal.cache.CreateRegionProcessor$CreateRegionMessage.process(CreateRegionProcessor.java:369)
```
So, that case is already covered.

Currently when an existing member adds an AEQ id that isn't defined in another member, no exception is thrown. The exception happens when a put occurs like:
```
Caused by: org.apache.geode.internal.cache.wan.GatewaySenderConfigurationException: Region data has [db] AsyncEvent queue IDs. Another cache has same region with [db2, db] AsyncEvent queue IDs. For region across all members, AsyncEvent queue IDs should be same.
	at Remote Member '192.168.1.2(25386)<v1>:41001' in org.apache.geode.internal.cache.PartitionedRegion.checkSameSenderIdsAvailableOnAllNodes(PartitionedRegion.java:1295)
	at Remote Member '192.168.1.2(25386)<v1>:41001' in org.apache.geode.internal.cache.LocalRegion.notifyGatewaySender(LocalRegion.java:6217)
	at Remote Member '192.168.1.2(25386)<v1>:41001' in org.apache.geode.internal.cache.BucketRegion.notifyGatewaySender(BucketRegion.java:716)
	at Remote Member '192.168.1.2(25386)<v1>:41001' in org.apache.geode.internal.cache.LocalRegion.basicPutPart2(LocalRegion.java:5863)
	at Remote Member '192.168.1.2(25386)<v1>:41001' in org.apache.geode.internal.cache.BucketRegion.basicPutPart2(BucketRegion.java:701)
	at Remote Member '192.168.1.2(25386)<v1>:41001' in org.apache.geode.internal.cache.map.RegionMapPut.doBeforeCompletionActions(RegionMapPut.java:282)
	at Remote Member '192.168.1.2(25386)<v1>:41001' in org.apache.geode.internal.cache.AbstractRegionMap.basicPut(AbstractRegionMap.java:2044)
	at Remote Member '192.168.1.2(25386)<v1>:41001' in org.apache.geode.internal.cache.BucketRegion.virtualPut(BucketRegion.java:527)
	at Remote Member '192.168.1.2(25386)<v1>:41001' in org.apache.geode.internal.cache.LocalRegionDataView.putEntry(LocalRegionDataView.java:162)
	at Remote Member '192.168.1.2(25386)<v1>:41001' in org.apache.geode.internal.cache.LocalRegion.basicUpdate(LocalRegion.java:5672)
	at Remote Member '192.168.1.2(25386)<v1>:41001' in org.apache.geode.internal.cache.AbstractUpdateOperation.doPutOrCreate(AbstractUpdateOperation.java:150)
	at org.apache.geode.internal.cache.BucketRegion.basicPutPart2(BucketRegion.java:691)
	at org.apache.geode.internal.cache.map.RegionMapPut.doBeforeCompletionActions(RegionMapPut.java:282)
	at org.apache.geode.internal.cache.tier.sockets.command.Put65.cmdExecute(Put65.java:392)
```
In that case, the region has the entry, but it wasn't sent to the AEQ.
Closing for reconsideration.

@Petahhh

Please do not merge a PR with a failing precheckin without commenting on the nature of the failing test, such as if there is an existing ticket or known issue.  Without some external knowledge, it seems as though this merge should be reverted until that test failure can be resolved.

@PurelyApplied This failure is form of known issue GEODE-6326 (https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GEODE-6326).  I did not know it was policy to comment on the PR if a known unrelated failure occurs.  The failure is related to eventual consistency when concurrent events are applied to a region.  This PR adds the ability to specify identity fields using JSON formatter, which is a completely unrelated part of the code base.  Still, I'm happy to comment on future PRs with the known ticket number if that is now our policy.  I have also retriggered the PR pipeline in previous PRs, and can do that as well, but I'm not sure if its worth the resources just to prove that a known issue is known/flakey.

Oh, I don't know that we have an official policy.  I was just trying to say that, if you know what the issue is (which I assume you do since you'll have investigated your test failures), then I personally appreciate having those breadcrumbs.

Although maybe we should have a policy... I should probably send something out to the dev list about it.

Hey @jhuynh1 ,

Thanks for reviewing this.
The PR actually attacks both issues: it prevents the `pool` from being destroyed if it's still in use by at least one region (see [here](https://github.com/apache/geode/pull/3569/files?file-filters%5B%5D=.java#diff-8d7c80296713855c7f737671ad251e9aR169)) _and_ also checks wether the `pool` actually exists before trying to use it to execute the `function`, thus preventing the `NPE` altogether and throwing something more meaningful (see [here](https://github.com/apache/geode/pull/3569/files?file-filters%5B%5D=.java#diff-0bd9c9c821a42fe9e3ed0f32d44ba450R124)).
That said, I've changed the GEODE ticket to reflect more closely the changes, thanks!.
Cheers.
this received a passing review...please rebase to latest develop so checks can re-run

I am not seeing how we are better off trading a NPE for a ISE. What calls this method to unregister the pool? Shouldn't those call points be updated to not call this method if there are regions attached to the pool?
The ticket references `PoolManagerImpl.getPMI().unregister(PoolManager.find("poolOne"));`, which is not a public API. Is this the only way in which the region is being unregistered?
We intend to create a separate PR for this; please do not review.

Hey @pivotal-jbarrett,

Thanks for reviewing this.

> I am not seeing how we are better off trading a NPE for a ISE.

Anything is better than a `NPE` if you ask me, the `IllegalStateException` actually lets the user know that the `Pool` can not be unregistered because some regions are still using it. The `NPE`, on the other hand, doesn't let them know anything about the problem and how to prevent/overcome it.

> What calls this method to unregister the pool? Shouldn't those call points be updated to not call this method if there are regions attached to the pool?

We only expect the `PoolImpl` to invoke this method during the `destroy` operation (at least within Geode code), and at this point the `PoolImpl` already checked the internal status to make sure the `Pool` can be unregistered.

> The ticket references PoolManagerImpl.getPMI().unregister(PoolManager.find("poolOne"));, which is not a public API. Is this the only way in which the region is being unregistered?

Yeah, that was an example I used to reproduce the issue I've seen. Ideally nobody should call this method as it is part of the internal API but, in case somebody does, this PR checks for the actual region count and prevents the `Pool` from being unregistered if needed.

Let me know your thoughts.
Cheers.

@Petahhh
@Petahhh

A new interface `CacheMarker` is added to indicate Cache instance. `ClientCache` and `Cache` are all just interfaces, the code (before or after) eventually will need to cast the object to `GemfireCacheImpl` to get to the methods it needs to do the calculation. So in another words, taking a `Cache` or `CacheMarker` is no difference.
I am still struggling to understand how, through normal API usage, we can end up in this situation?

> I am still struggling to understand how, through normal API usage, we can end up in this situation?

I think this is where a DUnit test could really help, because I wasn't able to see how we get into this state either.  I think @jujoramos is working on one now.

@pivotal-jbarrett @mcmellawatt

I've been digging through the code and, theoretically, we can't end up in this situation using just *public regular API*.
A client, however, can potentially call [PoolManagerImpl.unregister(Pool poll)](https://github.com/apache/geode/blob/develop/geode-core/src/main/java/org/apache/geode/internal/cache/PoolManagerImpl.java#L168-L182) and break our internal invariants, basically by removing a `Pool` from the internal map when there are still regions attached to that `Pool` (which in turn might cause the NPE [here](https://github.com/apache/geode/blob/develop/geode-core/src/main/java/org/apache/geode/internal/cache/execute/InternalFunctionExecutionServiceImpl.java#L119L120) afterwards).
The changes from this PR [prevent the above](https://github.com/apache/geode/pull/3569/files#diff-8d7c80296713855c7f737671ad251e9aR171) from happening and also, if it happens (for whatever unknown reason at this point), it [throws a meaningful exception](https://github.com/apache/geode/pull/3569/files#diff-0bd9c9c821a42fe9e3ed0f32d44ba450R125) to the user instead of the NPE.
The [test](https://github.com/apache/geode/pull/3569/files#diff-2603186f6bc647221ba8d72e979edfc3R436) added in the latest commit might help to clarify this, please let me know your thoughts.
Cheers.
@gemzdude @BenjaminPerryRoss

@jdeppe-pivotal This is related to the changes I've been looking at.  This PR will solve the case where the same jar is redeployed, but it won't handle the case where an unrelated jar is deployed.  For example if we deploy jar A and put some keys into the region that used classes in jar A, if we then deploy jar B, we would still create a new class loader containing both A and B but the same problem of instanceof checks would exist.

My current WIP to chain classloaders is at:  
https://github.com/apache/geode/pull/3537
I am not sure if it will be a valid solution until I test it out a bit more but precheckin has passed.

After talking with Jens, we think using different builder in different context would be better, this would make the separation easier and also not forcing us to expose the ClientClusterManagementService implementation. Will change the PR to reflect that.

Yaml changes were tested in a personal pipeline, so this PR is ready to go if everyone is happy with the changes described.

Strictly speaking, this PR actually shortens the feedback time by 2 hours.  Before, all Linux tests ran, then all Windows tests ran.  Now they run at the same time.  I agree it would be great to get that even shorter.  But I disagree that all of that work must be done as part of _this_ PR.

recent changes (last few days) should make the integration tests a lot less red.  we have already tried the "let's keep the tests hidden until they're super solid, then bring them in" approach for the last 8 months, and it hasn't worked, so the point here is to try the opposite approach

> recent changes (last few days) should make the integration tests a lot less red. we have already tried the "let's keep the tests hidden until they're super solid, then bring them in" approach for the last 8 months, and it hasn't worked, so the point here is to try the opposite approach

I would argue it has worked in that it has show the community is not interested in integration testing on Windows. A different response to that signal may be to just remove the Windows integration tests completely. Something in the middle says find a set of integration tests that actually test integration points unique to Windows.

Formally declaring that we don't support Windows & abandoning all Windows tests would also be a valid outcome of this discussion, with sufficient consensus (and probably at least one release cycle announcing intended deprecation followed by actual de-supporting in next major).

> Formally declaring that we don't support Windows & abandoning all Windows tests would also be a valid outcome of this discussion, with sufficient consensus (and probably at least one release cycle announcing intended deprecation followed by actual de-supporting in next major).

A less drastic approach is to continue the "support" we have, which is vaguely tested and assumed to work based on the Java "promise" of write once run anywhere.
@jdeppe-pivotal @jinmeiliao @onichols-pivotal

> Work should be done to improve feedback time. Windows testing takes a lot more time than Linux testing.
> Acceptance 2x slower
> Distributed (subset) 1.5x slower
> Integration (rarely green) 10x slower
> 
> This expands the feedback time from about 2 hours to over 4 hours.
> 
> Integration tests need to be fixed before this is accepted too. They are currently way more red than green. Feedback on failed Windows integration run takes 5 hours.

Can anyone weigh in on any obvious reason why all Windows jobs take so much longer?  My apologies if I missed an earlier explanation.

>Can anyone weigh in on any obvious reason why all Windows jobs take so much longer? My apologies if I missed an earlier explanation.

Either because they are still not dockerized like Linux so they can't run in parallel or they are so flaky that parallelization had to be reduced.
@onichols-pivotal I think it sets a bad precedent for merges to occur on PRs that have unresolved reviews.
When viewing the dashboard its just red or green boxes, does it really matter how tall it is when viewing the pipeline? I feel like the dashboard view is more common to watch, is it not?

Yes, to clarify, please view this PR as _optional_.  I put it out to give people a chance to weigh in on which layout is preferred.  If the majority are ok with the one-tall-stack I'd love to close this without merging.
